channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Scrooge had it right! Perl role in Vienna
item.description: Perl programmers, are you ready to get your Scrooge on and help others save money? Here’s what you need to know: this company is looking for someone who will deliver strong content and well-executed info to keep their users in the black. This client is located in Vienna, Austria, and is looking for candidates with strong Modern Perl, PostgreSQL and Elasticsearch.

item.title: Let’s do an experiment! Perl role in Canberra, Australia
item.description: This thoughtful company helps to develop new species of plants. They deliver cost-efficient genotyping technology that promotes the development of better, stronger crops adapted to suit their environment. On a planet whose climate is changing, it sounds like the place to be is on the team designing hardy plants for our brave new world! Looking for a Modern Perl developer to join their team.

item.title: Wanted: Senior Perl developers with good karma. Remote Perl within UK, South Africa and Switzerland
item.description: Our client is a multinational fundraising group that works with thousands of charities to provide cloud-based management tools, a dedicated social fundraising platform, and a secure channel for charities to receive funds. They're looking for a strong Perl developer who also has automated payment experience.

item.title: What would your computer say about you? Perl, Python, NLP role in Amsterdam
item.description: Our client is the worldwide leader in machine intelligence for matching people with jobs, which is to say that when it comes to hiring, they know what they’re doing. Applicants, bring your “A” game: they’re looking for a Natural Language Processing (NLP) Engineer who has strong Perl and Python

item.title: Pop Quiz and Your New Perl Role! 100% Remote within UK
item.description: This is the role for you if you want start-up vibes in an established company. Not feeling the urge to commute during these socially distanced times and beyond? Not a problem. The role is 100% remote-friendly for folks in the UK. The client is interested in anyone with experience building web apps in Perl, using one of the major Perl frameworks.

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great CPAN modules released last week;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 130: An Odd Tree
item.description: Roger shared a Raku version of the Odd Number task. I loved the Postscript solution.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 130
item.description: For the first task, Luis, used YAML for his tree representation. It made the search really fun.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 130: quick
item.description: I hate trees with a passion! sums up all the emotion by Luca. However we still got clean Raku code.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 130: Odd Number and Binary Search Tree
item.description: Laurent's use of a Bag to solve the Odd Number task gives us a clean one-liner. For BST, a recursive function is used.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge #130
item.description: Nice use of a bitwise operator to deal with the Odd Number task. Cool hack to flatten the tree before checking if it is BST.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge Club - 130
item.description: Ian is on a declarative coding kick and is enjoying the Tree task. Keep it up.

item.title: PWC130 - Binary Search Tree
item.description: For a change, we have the Perl solution first followed by Raku.

item.title: PWC130 - Odd Number
item.description: I love the fact that the Perl solution looks like Raku and not the other way. Nice attempt.

item.title: A First Pass at Object::Pad
item.description: Pretty cool example and use of Object::Pad. Thanks for your contribution.

item.title: The Odd Tree with Raku and Perl
item.description: Cool demo of dot and svg. Keep it up and thanks for sharing.

item.title: These Binary Trees are Odd
item.description: Adam used struct to deal with the BST task. Thanks for sharing your knowledge.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 130: Odd Number
item.description: Abigail shared cool solutions in not just Perl but also some other languages.

item.title: Perl Review - Perl Weekly Challenge - 128
item.description: Perl Solutions Review by Colin Crain.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 130
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions by Team PWC dealing with the "Odd Number" and "Binary Search Tree" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 131
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks "Consecutive Arrays" and "Find Pairs". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read the FAQ.

item.title: Monthly Report - August
item.description: Time for monthly report, little late though.

item.title: Next steps of research study launched - interviewees wanted
item.description: Looking for interviewees.

item.title: My Favorite Warnings: redundant and missing
item.description: Tom sharing his favourites warnings.

item.title: How to show UTF-8 at the Windows command prompt
item.description: Yuki sharing how to deal with UTF-8 in Windows.

item.title: Ann Barcomb study: Survey launch
item.description: Another survey launched.

item.title: Travis CI flaw exposed secrets of thousands of open source projects
item.description: Find the details of CI flaw.

item.title: Board update September 2021
item.description: Daniel Sockwell has joined the Board.

item.title: #530 - Outreachy 2021
item.description:
Hi there

If you remember, I mentioned the Outreachy program in the editorial of the weekly newsletter edition #522. It has finally come to an end as Rosheen Naeem successfully completed the internship as reported by the TPF in a blog post. Congratulations Rosheen.

The Perl Foundation is looking for mentors and project ideas for the next Outreachy rounds. If you have Perl or Raku project ideas, please get in touch with TPF.

Many years ago, I was approached for help by the Open Food Facts team as they found out about my distribution, Food::ECodes. Unfortunately it didn't work out as I was too busy with my other pet projects. I hope one day I can contribute to Open Food Facts. I remember I had trouble setting up a local development environment for my contributions. I haven't had a chance to see if there has been any improvements in this area to help newcomers to contribute.

I request Perl fans to come forward and help the cool fun project Open Food Facts.

Enjoy the rest of the newsletter and stay safe.
